citeinfo.title: Storm Water Collection System Points - City of Newton

descript.abstract: This coverage contains point features such as manholes, catchbasins, ditch ends, dry wells, pipe junctions, pipe ends and outfalls which comprise part of the storm water collection network for the city of Newton. Line features such as pipes and ditches are contained in the Storm Water Collection System Lines data layer.
descript.purpose:
This layer is intended for researchers, students, and policy makers and planners for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data.
This layer may provide a basemap for layers related to urban planning, public works, or utilities purposes (including defining boundaries, managing assets and facilities, integrating attribute databases with geographic features, spatial analysis, and presentation output.
descript.supplinf: This data layer is not presently being maintained; however, the Department of Public Works is attempting to start a project to field check the drain infrastructure and resolve some of the many discrepancies.

idinfo.accconst: Access is granted to licensee (Harvard University) only. Available only to Harvard University affiliates.
idinfo.useconst: For educational or non-commercial use only.
idinfo.datacred: GIS data supplied by City of Newton GIS.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows NT Version 4.0 (Build 1381) Service Pack 6; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.2.0.700

dataqual.logic: This data layer is known to contain errors in content and in the connections between features. This data layer should be regarded as a draft and other sources, specifically the as-built construction drawings, should be consulted as appropriate.

horizpa.horizpar: Manhole and catch basin locations mapped based on photogrammetric locations have an absolute accuracy of +/- 2.5 feet. The accuracy of the other manhole and catch basin locations is unknown. The accuracy of the pipe features is unknown.

citeinfo.title: James W. Sewall Co. Aerial Photography

srcinfo.srccontr: Mapping of water/sewer/drain infrastructure based on targets painted on the streets, conducted by the James W. Sewall Co. The aerial photographs were taken on April 15, 1994. The photographs were produced at a scale of 1" = 600' at an approximate altitude above datum of 3,600 feet. The information below is from the J. W. Sewall Co. Proposal Documents Scale of Photography: 1:7200 Forward Overlap: 60% average within 5 feet. Side Overlap: 30% average within 10 feet Tilt: Not to exceed 3 degrees - 4 degrees between flight lines Crab: Not to exceed 3 degrees relative to flight line Contact Prints: 9" x 9" received from company. Ground Control: Primary - 12 permanent control markers set - 36" concrete monuments. GPS network of 50 stations with three horizontal and nine vertical ties to grid. Network tied to MSPCS NAD83 datum and NGVD29 datum by occupying Mass. Highway Department control points. Block Adjustment Accuracy: Horizontal: second order class I; Vertical: third order Model: ALBANY-Lite Final Pixel Size: 12 inches Final Horizontal Accuracy: Approximately +/- 5 feet.
Construction drawing ID's were taken from the existing atlas maps and added as an attribute of drain pipe segments

procstep.procdesc:
Storm drain manholes and catch basins were photogrammetrically captured from the aerial photography referred to in the introduction to this document. A field check of the area of four 1" = 40' scale Assessor's sheets showed that the capture rates for manholes and catch basins were, respectively, 95% and 90% correct. The figures for the manholes are, however, somewhat misleading. This is because at the time of the photography, the city was known to have instances of sewer manhole lids on storm drain manholes, and vice versa.
Data layer development was completed under contract with Applied Geographics, Inc. (AGI) of Boston. AGI was provided two kinds of source information: 1) The existing 1" = 400' scale atlas maps. 2) Storm drain catch basins and manhole locations mapped photogrammetrically from aerial photography taken in April 1994.
This data layer was created "on screen" with a back-drop of the point features from the aerial photography and other appropriate features from the city's GIS database (e.g., street rights-of-way). The contractor's staff then constructed the storm drain network while referencing both the on-screen features and features from the paper atlas. Construction drawing ID's were taken from the existing atlas maps and added as an attribute of drain pipe segments. This data layer is sufficient in most cases for providing a general idea as to the locations of these features on the ground.
The original shape file was imported to an ArcSDE Layer.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

enttyp.enttypd: ESRI Shapefile. Points represent water system features

edom.edomvd: Undefined. Only one feature of this type

attrvai.attrva: No explanation if they are self explanatory

attr.attrdef: Indicates the reliability of the information given potentially conflicting or disagreeing sources

edom.edomvd: Photo source and atlas source agree
Feature on the photo, but no match in the atlas
Feature appears in the atlas but was not mapped from the photos

attr.attrdef: Indicates that the pipe diameter has changed at this node
Source of an edit to the feature
The numeric identifier of the storm drain sub-basin that drains to the river through the outfall.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
